image.altText: A crowd of people walking along a street in a central business district in Melbourne on a sunny day.

props.synopsis: Australia's minimum wage and award wages will increase by 3.75 per cent from July 1, the Fair Work Commission has announced.

title.children: Minimum and award wages to increase by 3.75 per cent come July 1

image.altText: Wide angle picture looking up through long grasses to a high-voltage power line with the sun setting in the background

props.synopsis: Across Australia, huge numbers of consumers are slowly waking up to the presence of mysterious new power charges on their bills.

title.children: Charged a month for 'moment' of demand: Consumers angry at 'mysterious' power tariffs

image.altText: Search team on top of rubble from Whalan house explosion. Neighbouring house still standing behind them

props.synopsis: A body of a woman is found following a delicate and complex search in the rubble of a townhouse that exploded in Sydney's west on Saturday.

title.children: Body found after explosion at Sydney townhouse

image.altText: Five Cold Chisel band members sit in connected waiting room chairs. A pokie machine in front of them on the floor

props.synopsis: Cold Chisel went from a 'reckless' band unfit for radio plays to rock legends who've transcended the generations. This is why the Aussie band continues to be the soundtrack of our lives.

title.children: Radio called Cold Chisel 'unplayable'. Then Khe Sanh sent them on the road to rock legend status

image.altText: Kellie Ann Carmichael

props.synopsis: Victorian woman Kellie Ann Carmichael went missing after leaving a hostel in the Blue Mountains in 2001. Her remains have been found in bushland near Katoomba, with an investigation underway.

title.children: Remains found in Blue Mountains confirmed to be woman who went missing 23 years ago

image.altText: Journalist Antoinette Lattouf outside the fair work commission talking to the media

props.synopsis: Journalist and presenter Antoinette Lattouf was sacked by the ABC when she was taken off-air part way through a radio presenting stint, the Fair Work Commission has found.

title.children: Journalist Antoinette Lattouf was sacked by ABC, Fair Work Commission finds

image.altText: woman in black jacket gives inquiry evidence behind microphone

props.synopsis: A senior lawyer at the heart of the disastrous and deadly Robodebt scheme resigns after questions are raised as to why she kept her Commonwealth job while contracted with another legal firm.

title.children: Senior government lawyer at heart of Robodebt scheme resigns after being discovered consulting with outside firm

image.altText: Dr Max Mollenkopf smiles while standing on the footpath of a quiet Newcastle street on a bright, sunny day.

props.synopsis: Newcastle GP Max Mollenkopf says unnecessary appointments for medical certificates are wasting doctors' time.

title.children: Why this GP wants employers to stop asking for medical certificates

props.synopsis: Josh Frydenberg would need the Victorian Liberal party to make an "unprecedented" decision to discard Kooyong candidate Amelia Hamer and facilitate his political return.

title.children: 'I don't see it happening': Federal Liberal MP pours cold water on Frydenberg return

image.altText: a woman and her daughter standing smiling together

props.synopsis: Amid all the health workers coming in and out of Harlow's hospital room after her brain surgery, one stood out to her – diminutive neurosurgeon Amelia Jardim.

title.children: 'I love Amelia and will shout it from the rooftops': Harlow's neurosurgeon did more than just repair her brain

image.altText: Natasha Ryan arrives outside Brisbane Supreme Court

props.synopsis: The body of the now 40-year-old Rockhampton woman, who made international headlines after she ran away from home at 14 and hid in her boyfriend's house for five years, is found at Rockhampton Golf Club after a search by police.

title.children: Body of former teenage runaway Natasha Ryan found after search in Rockhampton

image.altText: A side-on close shot of a man wearing a blue suit and black glasses.

props.synopsis: Treasury secretary Steven Kennedy faces senators as a new national minimum wage affecting the pay of millions of Australians is set by the Fair Work Commission.

title.children: Treasury boss fronts estimates as wage decision announced

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Minimum and award wages to increase by 3.75 per cent
Penny Wong criticises opposition's ICC call
Treasury is up at Senate estimates today

image.altText: A composite image of two male politicians

props.synopsis: Donald Trump's predictable but uncomfortable rant against the judicial system and the rule of law is a challenge for Australia as Anthony Albanese makes a wild ride between upholding the bedrock of liberal democracy and keeping a potential future US president on side.

title.children: A second Trump presidency would be a wild ride for Australia and the stakes could not be higher

image.altText: A stock trader looks down at a tablet as he works on the floor of a busy stock exchange while surrounded by screens.

props.synopsis:
Wall Street's strong finish to the month is set to flow through to the ASX. The Fair Work Commission will release the increase for both the minimum and award wages for the year later this morning.

Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX set to rise, wage decision to be released as house prices rise again

image.altText: three men smiling shirtless in front of beach

props.synopsis: Drivers may have their vehicles towed away if they park overnight near the Noosa National Park as the local council tries to reduce noise and rubbish complaints.

title.children: Illegal campers hit with tow-away threats as parking fines fail to deter overnight stays

image.altText: A man in a dark coat stands among a military parade

props.synopsis: Thousands of people in Ukraine's north-east are displaced as Russia steps up its offensive in the area, which started with a surprise attack last month.

title.children: Putin's men appear to be advancing on a key Ukrainian city. But here's what he really might be up to

image.altText: Side by side photos of business logos for accounting firms Deloitte, PwC, KPMG and EY

props.synopsis: After a year of scandals, bad publicity and a carousel of parliamentary inquiries shining a light on the shadowy world of the big four global accounting firms, it's time for reform.

title.children: Are the big four accounting firms about to get a visit from the tax man?

image.altText: A composit image of cast members from Luxe Listings Sydney, the Oppenheim brothers and Chriselle from Selling Sunset.

props.synopsis: When it comes to reality television, the arguments and scandals of Married at First Sight aren't for everyone. So why does the real estate reality television genre continue to appeal to such a broad demographic, when other shows fail to?

title.children: Why are we all so hooked on watching luxury real estate shows?

image.altText: a white sign with "under offer' is standing infront of a block of units

props.synopsis: CoreLogic data shows property prices grew by 0.8 per cent during May, making it the largest monthly increase since October last year.

title.children: 'Mismatch between supply and demand' sends house prices soaring

image.altText: Palestinians look at burnt buildings and debris after an Israeli strike.

props.synopsis: Israel has accepted US President Joe Biden's Gaza ceasefire proposal but believes the framework deal is "in need of much more work", an aide to Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu says.

title.children: Israel accepts Biden's Gaza ceasefire proposal but believes it needs 'much more work', aide says

image.altText: Dennis Harvey, the brother of the Floreat murder victim, Jennifer Petelczyc.

props.synopsis: Ten days after Jennifer Petelczyc and her daughter Gretl were gunned down in their suburban Perth home, Jennifer's brother speaks of happy family memories and his enduring anger at the man who cut their lives short.

title.children: Brother of Floreat shooting victim tells of devastation at murders and anger at gunman

image.altText: Three photo strips side by side showing the erosion of the beach and dune movement over six years

props.synopsis: In South Australia, parts of the Coorong's coast are undergoing "incredible rates of change" due to climate change. What does that mean for more urbanised parts of our coast?

title.children: Rapidly disappearing Coorong coastline sparks warning for Australian coastal communities

image.altText: Ian McCartney in police uniform speaks at Senate Estimates in May 2021.

props.synopsis: The Australian Federal Police has told a parliamentary hearing it halted a years-long policy of allowing Chinese police to come and operate in Australia, following a 2019 incident exposed by the ABC's Four Corners program.

title.children: AFP stopped allowing Chinese police to operate in Australia after incident exposed by Four Corners

image.altText: Claudia Sheinbaum, wearing a white tailored coat, places her vote in a box marked "Presidencia"

props.synopsis: After an election campaign costing dozens of local candidates their lives, tackling organised crime violence will be on the agenda for Mexico's new president.

title.children: Mexico expected to elect first female president after campaign costing 38 local candidates' lives

image.altText: A below view image of the One-Way Loitering munition in flight

props.synopsis: An electrically powered drone able to travel almost 200 kilometres or loiter in the air for 30 minutes carrying a lethal payload will be brought into service by the Australian Army before the end of the year.

title.children: Australian Army to bring 'the Owl', a locally made lethal drone, into service within months

image.altText: aerial rooftops in inner suburbs

props.synopsis: There's a reason Brisbane has overtaken Canberra and Melbourne for house prices, writes Ellen Fanning, who found herself in the city's cut-throat property market last year — competing with too many newcomers for a limited supply of homes.

title.children: Brisbane sheds its sleepy image with surging house values — now only second to Sydney

image.altText: Alistair Thomson stands in front of the West MacDonnell Ranges.

props.synopsis: Northern Territory Police locates the body of 64-year-old Alistair Thomson, who went missing on the Larapinta Trail in Central Australia more than a week ago.

title.children: 'Extremely terrible': NT Police locates body of Victorian hiker who went missing along Larapinta Trail

image.altText: thrombolites in water with rainbow on horizon

props.synopsis: Aurora chasers in south-western WA may have caused irreversible damage to an ecological site at Lake Clifton hosting 2,000-year-old examples of the Earth's earliest life forms.

title.children: Aurora chasers may have damaged ancient ecological site

image.altText: Payne Haas breaks through a tackle from Cameron Munster

props.synopsis: Rugby league's fiercest rivalry is back for another year. Here's a quick guide to State of Origin Game I.

title.children: State of Origin is upon us. Here's what to know ahead of Game I

image.altText: A surgeon wheeling a child amputee in a hospital.

props.synopsis: Australian healthcare workers returning from Gaza describe the region as a "prison", with many patients forced to take over-the-counter pain relief drugs after life-threatening amputations.

title.children: Australian doctors returning from 'hell on Earth' Gaza call for 'humanity to prevail'

props.synopsis: Australia today has 352,000 fewer people than expected because of the pandemic migration slump, according to an ANU professor, cutting against talk of a post-pandemic 'surge', which has been the subject of much political attention.

title.children: Has there been a surge in migrant arrivals? The answer may not be so straightforward

image.altText: A couple and their dog in front of a truck.

props.synopsis: Families of truck drivers worry every time they hear of a crash. Recent high-profile accidents on Australian roads involving heavy vehicles have highlighted concerns about the safety of the transport industry.

title.children: 'He might not come home': What it's like to be married to a truck driver

image.altText: Cage-diving with a big shark

props.synopsis: Shark fatalities on a remote coastline west of Adelaide accounted for 30 per cent of all shark deaths last year. But while other states pour millions of dollars into mitigation programs, the SA government says it is still working on a plan.

title.children: As mitigation programs ramp up elsewhere, this shark attack hotspot still goes without
